Definition: In this job, your task is to categorize a statement, received from online platforms, into one of two categories: Identity-attack and Non-identity-attack. Anything harsh or derogatory regarding someone's identity, such as their looks, race, gender, or sexual orientation, is considered an identity attack.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: Silly Americans, laws are for poor people.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment contains identity attacks on Americans.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: More annoying drivel from plagiarist Wente.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment is unrelated and does not contain identity attacks.

Negative Examples.explanation: This comment should be non-identity-attack because it is not disrespectful to any groups.

Negative Examples.input: Comment: The Canadian gang of fools at the table.
Negative Examples.explanation: This should be identity-attack because the comment contains identity attacks on Canadian.

Comment: I have never in 27 years refused anyone communion, Dennis. In any new parish I was appointed to, I'd watch who wasn't going to communion. That generally opened up the door for them to discuss their situation and I could take it from there. The important thing for me was to open the door.

One man had been with the same woman for over forty years. It was his second marriage. He took full responsibility for the failure of the first (he was a teenager and said he was immature. Comment: This can be confusing because everyone seems to have their own point of reference. You are correct that Juneau clock time now is closely equal to solar time during winter (Alaska Standard Time). During the summer now (under Alaska Daylight Savings Time) Anchorage is 2 hours ahead and Juneau is 1 hour ahead from solar time. Under MacKinnon's bill this relationship would remain and Juneau would be on same clock time as the west coast in the winter (when the west coast "falls back") but be one hour ahead of solar time. Central Alaska would be 2 hours ahead of solar time year-round. Ironically, back when Southeast was on Pacific Time for "convenience" sake, they were 1 hour ahead of solar time in the winter and 2 hours ahead during Daylight savings time in the summer. There is actually only a 1 hour 2 minute difference in solar time between Juneau and Anchorage. I hope I didn't make this more confusing - LOL

I read recently about a gay man who was not permitted to sing the Ave Maria at his grandmother's funeral -- despite the fact that the man is a life-long Catholic, was not in a relationship, and was known to the priest. Comment: Unfortunately it's not quite that simple.  There are lots of online calculators that will analyze rent vs. buy numbers for you:  http://www.getsmarteraboutmoney.ca/tools-and-calculators/buy-or-rent-calculator/buy-or-rent-calculator.aspx#.WLmEMG_ytpg 
If renting was always a waste of money, then everyone would buy a place no matter how high the cost, and that's clearly not a good idea.  There is always a breaking point beyond which house prices are high enough that it makes more financial sense to rent.  $2500 on rent might be a waste if it costs $2500 a month to buy the same place and one plans on staying there in the long term, but it's rare in today's market that the rental cost would be anywhere close to the total costs of ownership of an equivalent property.   According to the Economist, Canada has one of the highest price/rent ratios in the world, meaning that renting is comparatively cheap: economist.com/blogs/dailychart/2011/11/global-house-prices

Comment: Just having a gold plated pension plan isn't a guarantee of a good retirement, for Other factors have to be considered.

Has the person met the rule of, for example, 85?  Unless the person has met this rule, the person will not get full pension.

Is the pension fully indexed to inflation?  Or is it only partially indexed or not indexed at all?  Without indexing, a pension that funds a good retirement at the beginning will be eaten away by inflation.

What is the person's life expectancy?  For a person who expects to be around for a long time after retirement, the previous comment about indexing becomes even more important.

What kind of lifestyle will the person lead in retirement.  If a person expects to travel a lot more, for example, more savings and assets may be more important.

Comment: This legal clause doesn't absolve BikeTown's operator of liability -- at worst, it lessons it and shifts a proportional amount on the user. And cyclists can opt out with an email or by not using BikeTown at all. No one has to take risks they don't accept. 

This clause has been characterised as an underhanded corporate gambit. But I believe BikeTown's operator, Motivate, is actually a progressive enterprise trying to create greener cities. It'll do this by establishing a stable business model for a financially tough industry. 

Another point is that BikeTown doesn't cost local taxpayers anything. That's unique. In the US, systems normally take a 20-70 percent operating subsidy -- and it's higher in Europe. If Portland isn't happy with this liability arrangement, it'll have to ante up to cover the operator's insurance burden.

Bottom line is that bike-sharing stands to make Portland's streets safer and users trimmer. Helmets or not, it'll be a net benefit for Portlanders' health.

Comment: You are making up your own history. All of our ancestors were immigrants, and not all that long ago. My Prussian great-grandfather, college-educated and skilled as a ship-builder, came to one of the many "Germantown" type settlements in the U.S. in the late 1800s, never did speak or read English without difficulty, worked as a cabinet-maker for a railroad here, and had a difficult life. America has been built by immigrants. That's what we are.

Comment: As for index ETFs outperforming index funds, that somewhat confusing paragraph is actually comparing index ETFs to the raw index (a theoretical entity). In a perfect world, index ETFs would match their underlying index, less fees, but in the real world they're not perfectly efficient due to periodic changes in the index and fluctuating numbers of units outstanding. The theoretical index makes changes instantaneously but the fund sponsor has to go to the market when attempting to fulfill their mandate of replicating it or issuing new units. When changes are announced in advance, there is an opportunity for arbitrageurs to trade on the change in demand of securities that are either being added or dropped from said index. The arbitrageurs profit at the expense of ETF unitholders, Smaller funds that track lesser known indices are especially vulnerable to this problem.

For more info see: https://www.bu.edu/rbfl/files/2013/09/Issue2McLaughlin.pdf

Comment: Wow, it's surprising to find a Globe editorial this poorly informed.  Most studies show that electric cars, even when they're powered from "dirty" electric sources are STILL more environmentally friendly than gasoline cars.  This is because electricity is much more efficient at being used, so when a car gets electricity to operate, it uses nearly 100% of that energy, a gas car uses approximately 20% of it's energy, with 80% being wasted.  The Globe's stance also ignores the exceptionally polluting ways oil is taken out of the ground, and the toxic way it is turned to gasoline.  It's remarkably short sighted to assume that our power will always come from dirty sources.  Tesla is making it easier for people to have their own solar energy at home--this is the way of the future, and truly, our best chance at avoiding catastrophe.  As for the subsidies, they're a drop in the bucket compared to the multi-billions given to the oil industry--no one complains about that.

Comment: House Bill (HB) 3337 was passed by the state legislature in 2007, and required that Eugene and Springfield adopt separate Urban Growth Boundaries (UGB’s). HB 3337 identified a completion date of December 31, 2009 for assessing whether Eugene has a sufficient supply of land within the UGB to meet the projected demand for residential, commercial, industrial, and public/semi-public land over the next 20 years.

The assessment has not yet been completed, after eight years of city floundering and six-and-a-half years past the deadline.

The work that has been done utterly fails to provide any pragmatic strategies for providing adequate workforce housing. The entire "Envision Eugene" model is based on workforce households that don't _already_ own a home living in apartments, rather than buying a home.
 
Because of this neglect, single-family homes prices will increase much faster than household income, exacerbating the housing affordability problem.

(continued ...)

Comment: Krugman is not playing some "rhetorical trick"; he's simply relaying mainstream scientific opinion on the impacts of climate change. Civilization as we know it simply will not be able to exist on a planet where the climate changes as much and as fast as now. 

And if you're one of those saying that we will adapt, you should consider that climate changes less rapid than now are associated with major extinction events in the geological record. 

During the End Permian extinction 250mya,  for instance, the build up of greenhouse gasses in the atmosphere played a key role in transforming the planet into a hot, lifeless orb, yet those GHG accumulated at a fraction of the rate we're seeing now.

Comment: It is necessary to point out that what Brizdle describes as "assumptions" are actually estimated values fitted in to the standard transportation model. And because Bridzle knows nothing about the model, or its underlying coefficients he thinks everything falls apart. It doesn't. What happens if there is a 1 percent change in any of the things he mentions? There is a less than 1 percent change in ridership. So the whole thing doesn't fall apart. It means less riders. The model is also applied to the bus. Big deals are commute time, the price of gasoline, and above all population along the route. And the "assumptions", read values, are  themselves are quite conservative.Population along the route is already above $600,000. And that's from the 2010 Census. What's happening here is someone is completely confused about this, doesn't know how these variables were arrived at, and spreads the confusion. Joined in by other who are equally confused. It's really a tiresome, troublesome spectacle.

Comment: Not at all clear what the author is trying to say. What does it mean, for example, that '(Cosby's) jury’s marathon deliberation put America’s Dad – and others – on notice'. How so? How does the fact the deliberations are protracted figure in her analysis?

Hopefully progress is being made in 'how society treats sexual assault'. In Cosby's case, the state had originally declined to prosecute citing insufficient evidence or credibility. And so she went the civil route where the burden of proof is less demanding. The fact it was revisited years later and charges laid is de-facto proof that attitudes have changed. 

But there are limits to the public's willingness to take the victim's word at face value - especially where money and celebrity are involved, and even more when there are long gaps between the assault and the complaint. If true (and it might well be) doesn't each victim have a duty to prevent it happening again - even at some personal inconvenience or embarrassment?

Comment: Hello GH - If I am understanding you correctly, you want the government to step in and tell unit owners they cannot rent out their units. If this is correct and you fear that your condo building will turn into an apartment building, you should probably sell your unit and rent/buy a house somewhere else. The government would be foolish to make any changes that you allude to in your post. First, the number of available rentals would likely decrease significantly, since roughly three times as many condo buildings as opposed to apartment buildings have been built over the past decade. Further, if these units are removed from the rental market, then the rental prices will increase (i.e., supply is less than demand). Second, condo purchases would likely decrease, since who would want to buy a unit if they cannot rent it out if needed. I hope the government does not do as you suggest they should.

Comment: Not fear mongering, realistic. Loussac had to close for several days due to a bed bug outbreak and the building had to be fumigated to get rid of the problem. The homeless population and those in low-income households have high rates of bed bug infestations. I work in social services and this is a rampant problem. The library has become a haven, a hangout place for this population and has made it more attractive, weakening the mission statement: "Anchorage Public Library provides resources to enrich the lives and empower the future of our diverse community while preserving the past for generations to come." The library is there to offer patrons a safe place to read and to educate - it's not a social service agency. There are both non-profit and state agencies that do this work. People don't feel their lives enriched if they have to avoid going to a library that doesn't have security and lets people in with bed bugs, who are high, intending to use the facilities as their own space.

Comment: Time Zones in Alaska were permanently changed in 1983. Prior to that the width of Alaska required five time zones to allow the Sun to be aligned somewhat with the noon hour.  Now we have just two time zones (Alaska and Aleutian/Hawaiian). We observe DST in only the Alaska Time Zone.  The effect of this can be seen during the period of DST when the Sun is highest in the sky at 2:00 PM in Anchorage and 3:00 PM in Nome.  

This change was done to placate Juneau who at that time was in the Pacific Time Zone with Seattle. Between them and the original Alaska Time Zone (Railbelt region)  was the Yukon Time Zone..  Anchorage was then two hours behind Juneau and that difference was used as a further justification to move the capital into the time zone where most of the states people and commerce were located. Bill Sheffield was behind this change and, as stated, the entire state (except the far Aleutians) were forced into a new Alaska Time Zone.  

Now can we just please stop changing clocks?

Comment: I read a lot of comments from people who never rode a motorcycle, or have but have never split lanes in trafic.There are number of good reasons why this practice should be allowed and when done properly is safer for motorcycle riders. The fact that many car drivers never look in rear view mirror is not new to motorcycle riders, when riding a motorcycle the golden rule is to ride as if you are invisible. Having said that I have always split lanes in trafic (despite the risk of getting a ticket) for my well being is more valuable then a trafic violation and less dangerous then being crushed between two cars. While perched on a motorcycle , a rider can see way ahead and easily anticipate erratic and sudden changes in trafic flow making it easier to adjust your speed and trajectory. A rider is also undistracted by other passengers, cell phone , media player and is much more aware of the environment in which he is traveling .

Comment: There are several MAJOR problems with this though:

1. Cap 'n Trade only covers a small proportion of greenhouse gas emissions while actually subsidizing some other forms of emissions.  The end result is more of a shift in where the emissions occur rather than an outright decline in emissions

2. The increase in cost is most effective in changing demand when that increase is transparent and obvious.  When gas goes up by 4 cents/litre and you don't know whether it is due to Cap 'n Trade or a hurricane in Texas it is less likely to change your behaviour than if you can see the change.

3. The heavily bureaucratic nature of the system discourages innovation

4. Ironically if/when GHG emissions are reduced it reduces demand for carbon credits, there-by decreasing the price and, perversely, this decreases the incentive to reduce GHG emissions

Cap and Trade exists for the purpose of obfuscating costs and spending.  If GHG emissions are reduced that is a bonus, but not the primary goal.

Comment: 2/2
This could be flipped into either a tri-level or four-leveled democracy over perhaps several decades without  excessive disruption. The key element should be a diocesan synod composed of all clergy and elected representative from every parish, with the bishop as president of the synod, but democratically subject to his synod for legislation.

The bishop would continue to appoint pastors, who would become presidents of each parish synod composed of elected parishioners.

If the Bishop of Rome were elected by all 5000 or so bishops, we would have a tri-level democracy. I would prefer to see diocese grouped into provinces of about 25 dioceses, and then have the bishops of each province elect one of their number to sit on a permanent synod in Rome. This permanent synod would elect the Bishop of Rome, and the pope would rule as prime minister (PM) of the synod.  The  PM forms the government (curia), but all legislative authority would remain with the Roman synod.

Comment: Luggage in hand, I walked through the front door of the terminal and out the back. Someone pointed me toward my plane, I deposited my bags with the others and ascended the steps to the aircraft where I was given a warm welcome while a copy of my ticket was pulled. That was it - almost surreal in its simplicity. Alas that age of innocence is long gone - replaced by an onerous, oppressive, expensive process designed to give us at least the illusion of security.

In the wake of Air India and 9/11, air travel is now as pleasant as a root canal without the sedative. There's no excuse for the bad behaviour increasingly in evidence from airline staff and passengers alike, but it can be explained in large part by the complicated, stressful, almost adversarial environment in which these people find themselves. The idea you can process passengers in factory mode, pack them in sardine cans, and ship them across the globe without at least some fuss from time to time is naive.

Comment: If you're healthy, remain calm, and have experience with cold water, it's highly unlikely you'll die of shock. Panicking because you think you're going to die just might kill you. It's best to wear a wool hat and a wetsuit, drysuit, long underwear, or rain gear, but no cotton.  If you have suitable clothing and a PFD, you can survive for several hours, but your judgment and coordination will be lousy after about fifteen minutes. A PFD helps to reduce heat loss because you don't need use energy treading water.  The most dangerous part is when you get out of the water and it starts evaporating off you body. Wind makes it worse. It's surprising how much a hat helps. Also eating and keeping hydrated. It's a good idea to have at least two boats along with throw lines, safety equipment, and practice. Have a plan for what to do in the event of a capsize.

Comment: The analysis in this opinion piece fails for a number of reasons.  In 2015 the Oregon Department of Revenue published an analysis of Oregon's income tax using data from returns for tax year 2013.  The top 20% of taxpayers contributes 69% of the revenue collected by the income tax (page 19).  The problem is that our tax system is "too progressive" and allows many people to pay no tax at all.  Some returns are filed to get "free money" in refunds even though the filer paid no tax.  We need more taxpayers.  The bottom 40% of filers pays only a little over 4% of the income tax. Comment: That might be true in the US but not in Canada.

Our Constitution entrenches government funding of denominational schools (minority Catholic or Protestant schools as the case may be) in certain provinces as part of the Confederation bargain. This would be unthinkable in the US model. Adler v Ontario (AG), [1996] 3 S.C.R. 609 S. 93(1) of the Constitution Act, 1867 requires the Ontario government to fund Roman Catholic separate schools fully.

Prime Minister Stephen Harper observed that separation of church and state is an American constitutional concept and does not apply to the Canadian constitution. He went on to say that separation of church and state in Canada has meant, traditionally, that the government will not interfere with religion.

We do provide reasonable accommodation for religion as with the 2006 SCOC kirpan case - Multani v Commission scolaire Marguerite‑Bourgeoys.

In Ontario the Human Rights Code specifically mandates reasonable accommodation at S. 11(2).

Comment: I'd like to thank Mr. Quinn for his reasoned commentary on this issue. In his show, On the Coast, Stephen asked some very good questions of Mr. Dobrovolny and Councillors Louie and Affleck. My experience, in general, is that the city suffers from very poor approaches to decision making. First, there is significant hubris by many decision makers (and I have personally experienced this of Mr. Dobrovolny during his tenure as Head of Traffic Engineering). Secondly, where there is consultation it is often skewed, not open, meaningful consultation. Third, it is slow and reactive, lacking leadership, forethought and preparation. I think we can do better and as Stephen aptly points out, should there be a serious emergency such as a natural disaster, we must do better!

Comment: The law prohibits bartenders from serving drunk patrons or from serving alcohol to a person reasonably expected to become drunk (or drunker) on the drink. 
Personally, I blame both if the customer was served when acting drunk (it's like pornography, we all know it when we see it). As far as decisions go: wouldn't you prefer the bartender to err on the side of safety when he knows the guy is driving? 
In a perfect world, alcohol wouldn't be an addictive drug and drinkers would all stop drinking before inebriation. They don't. Reasonably, then, many states have determined that holding the profit-makers liable is the only way to cut down this dangerous practice. Bars are in the business of selling as much booze as they can. If left alone (obviously, not all of them), they'll send off any number of customers to drive who barely can walk out the door. 
Both the drinker and the bartender/tavern owner should be responsible: alcohol is dangerous stuff.

Comment: My Grandfather and Grandmother bought a piece of land before I was born. My family worked on clearing part of the land so they could build a cabin on it. It was made out of real rock my family gathered from the forest cast into blocks. A fortress. My grandfathers goal was to build it and retire there with my grandmother. She ended up having a stroke. He lost interest and just threw a roof on top of the unfinished building. After they both passed away, my parents & me kept going up to enjoy it. No running water, basic electricity and a wood stove my dad made. I grew up going there in the summer and even winters. I knew every stone in that area. 13 acres of pristine land on a private lake. It was time for my mother to retire, they were still paying for a mortgage. They ended up selling it over a decade ago, something I agreed to and now majorly regret. I found out just the other day that the new owner tore it down to build a rental cottage on it. Its eating me up.... Really depressing

Comment: [To Mr. Smith, the “sweet spot” for bikes in general is around $2,500, meaning for that amount average riders will get pretty much all the bike they’ll ever need.] 

Even that's a bit steep, especially considering that most riders haven't a clue on how to maintain and ride them. All sense of proportion is being lost, with many buyers thinking the more you pay, the better the machine, and they themselves have no idea how to buy something appropriate for their needs.

For the vast majority, an internal hub is the best choice. Unless you're racing , or have an intrinsic knowledge of how to use the machine, going for comfort should be the main goal. That being said, the internal hub market has grown, and there's some excellent choices.

For me, and an increasing number of others who know bikes, a classic high grade steel (manganese–molybdenum alloy) that's very springy and responsive is back in vogue (or never left in some cases like mine). Comfort, not weight, is the object for distance.

Comment: The coal market is on life support, and it is natural gas that is absorbing its market while renewables continue to mature. 

Wiki
In 2005 coal provided approximately 50% of electricity in the United States and about 92 percent of coal consumption went to electricity generation. However, in 2016, the EIA calculated that coal would provide only 30% of electricity generation nationwide with natural gas providing 34%, nuclear, 19%, and renewables, 15%.

By January 2016, more than 25% of coal production was in bankruptcy in the United States[8] including the top two producers Peabody Energy and Arch Coal.  By March 2017, the coal industry employed approximately 77,000 miners with 60,000 jobs having been eliminated since 2011. When Arch Coal filed for bankruptcy protection, the price of coal had dropped 50% since 2011 and it was $4.5 billion in debt.

Between vanishing market and debt...the coal industry is done.

Comment: This is one of those good news / bad news articles about retirement.

First the good news - it clearly outlines the pitfalls of RRSPs and RRIFs.

Now the bad news - contrary to Adrian Mastraccci's advice - you can have too much money in your RRSP and once it is in the RRSP/RRIF you have effectively given it back to the government and lost virtually all control over its taxation implications due to government mandated withdrawal rates.

The article makes no mention of either TFSA's (thank you Jim Flaherty) as a retirement planning tool or of unregistered investments.

It also doesn't make any mention of the impact of either private sector or public sector pension plans.

The real secret to paying less tax in retirement is to start planning early and to have a balanced investment portfolio of non-registered investments (note tax has already been paid on this money), TFSA funds and RRSPs/RRIFs.

This allows judicious planning of withdrawals to minimize taxes paid to wastrel governments.

Comment: "Am I still a Catholic?"

I hate getting into these kinds of things. The easy answer is -- Yes, you are still a Catholic until you formally join some other church. One could also say that the "reward" of a good Catholic Christian is not to be closer to the pope, but sanctity, to be closer to Christ. (One can be both, too. They are not mutually exclusive.) However, for a cradle Catholic (like me) in communion with the pope, as it were, the Petrine Office is far more favorable to the unity of the internal and spiritual resources of the 24 different Catholic Churches (Eastern and Western) than no office at all, no convergence, no focal point of unity. If one prays as I do that "all may be one," a believer would want this -- 24 Catholic different Catholic Churches attempting to live as one in Christ, sacramentally and organically. With that said, I do think you are still a Catholic, following your conscience, more to be understood and appreciated than to be followed by someone like me.

Comment: I'm pretty sure your math is a bit off.  The state income tax rate is a flat 4.63% and the max federal rate is 39.6, it comes out to slightly less than 44.25%.  Beyond that the way federal taxes work, you don't pay the 39% on 100% of your income.  So, I might suggest either you hire a better accountant or re-figure your math.  My wife and I fall in the federal 28% bracket.  Our effective rate was something closer to 22% once we figure in deductions, so even if you make enough to pay the full 39%, you probably aren't paying the full amount.  
While the hyperbole may sound good, it just proves how little you actually know about taxes.

Comment: Exedus, I think it's a joke to just think about the deficit without considering our debt! Virtually every economist will tell you that a country should run a deficit in bad times but reduce the debt in good times. Our current debt in Canada exceeds $1.3 TRILLION  and when (not if) interest rates increase to just 5%, the interest alone on our debt will be about $70 BILLION per year!! That 70 billion, each and every year could pay for a lot of things!
To further put the amount spent on interest payments in perspective, it is more than what is spent on pension benefits through the Canada and Quebec Pension Plans ($50.9billion), and is more than Canada’s total public spending on primary and secondary education!

Comment: In no case has anyone's vote consisted of a crime.  We already punish criminals adequately.  We do not revoke citizenship in our country, nor do we exile citizens as most nations did in the past, and as some still do.  If you think your dislike of any citizen is grounds to cancel a fundamental right of citizenship beyond the right to move freely about his country, I think you are not only wrong, but dangerous.  Indeeed, there are plenty of people who, for reason of their disapproval for one thing or another, would banish persons they don't even know from citizenship and even residence the nation of their citizenship.  We have law to prevent the practice of exile.  At some time in the future, if we get a decent high court, the right to vote of any citizen who is of majority age will be irrevocable.  It should not be a crime to vote.

Comment: The problem really IS oil if the issue is safety and not inconvenience.  The certainty of generational damage to our environment and economy, let alone the safety of citizens, is unavoidable if we suffer an event similar to those in other US and Canadian towns.  The Port of GH has a responsibility to protect our community in more ways than economic success.

Perhaps it's time to decide as a community how to prioritize our industries.  Some industrial projects do not coincide with the development of tourism or the sustainability of environmentally sensitive industries like, fishing, farming, and shellfish.  The Port of GH commissioners need to follow a comprehensive development plan for the region.  For the Port of GH to pursue their economic goals independent of our other industry's goals is a zero sum game.  It does not grow our economy as a whole, it simply supplants it.

If current Port commissioners can''t play on the same team as other industries, they need to be replaced.

Comment: 'Equality' has more than one nuance. What everyone seems to want is absolute equality, but that's communism. We are guaranteed by our Constitution to get what we earn; not an equal share of what is earned collectively; or 'equality of opportunity'.
But that is destroyed by the policies of our government that mandate employment quotas, educational scholarships and grants, even "equal opportunity housing" based on race or gender, not performance.
A performance based society also says that you are recognized by the most visible statistics - or the most noted actions - of the demographic that you identify with, whether that be by class, gender, or race. Right or wrong, you are known by the company you keep (Proverbs 13:20). 
It's very hard to view a people or demographic as marginalized when you see them being given more opportunities, yet they seem to demand more, or just take it from others.
Equality of opportunity requires equality of effort, of action, and of responsibility.

Comment: Continued. "There were no differences between nonusers and daily users in the specific regions of interest [nucleus accumbens, amygdala, hippocampus, and the cerebellum--areas high in cannabis receptors]. We found no evidence of differences in volumes b/t daily users and nonusers, adults or adolescents; alcohol consumption is associated with volume loss in the brain globally; even modest alcohol abuse may be associated with morphological changes and may represent an important confounding variable in studies on the effects of cannabis. And, "Cannabis use is not associated with structural changes within the brain as a whole or the hippocampus in particular" (Tzilos, G.K. et al., 2005, "Lack of Hippocampal Volume Change in Long-term heavy cannabis users" in American Journal of Addiction #14, pp.64-72). The take-away: we need more data before we start crowing about brain damage and volume loss in Sub-Cortical structures.

Comment: People, people, people!
The ACA was NOT about healthcare. It was about INSURANCE and taxes. 

I would like to see the ACA repealed, mostly because I think it's a bad law, excessively long (2000+ pages), probably in conflict with itself, and full of special carve-outs (Nebraska?).  But that's not likely to happen. Too many people have a vested interest in keeping it.

You have to schedule another appointment for that.}

Comment: If we're going to have an honest debate, we should all use the actual facts:
Congress in Section 6(i) of the Statehood Act prohibited the state from parting with
the title to its minerals. This section says, in part: The grants of mineral lands to the State of Alaska . . . are made upon the express condition that all sales, grants, deeds, or patents for any of the mineral lands so granted shall be subject to and contain a reservation to the State of all of the minerals in the lands so sold, granted, deeded, or patented . . . . Mineral deposits.   So when we asked for statehood we agreed that the STATE would retain ownership of the mineral tights.  Hence our constitution incorporates this mandate in dealing with mineral rights, holding in Section 8.11 that even when land was granted, the mineral rights were RESERVED by the State.    The State is required by section 8.2 of the constitution the develop is resources "for the maximum benefit of its people."  We have never been "owners".

Comment: When you have vast stands of even-aged lodgepole pine that is dead there is really no option other than clearcutting (or fire). You can try to leave non-host trees (the spruce and subalpine fir), but it is still essentially clearcutting (when pine is the lead species) and the "leave trees" often blow down during a significant wind event. Horse logging is, by its nature, small-scale and impracticable on a large scale and the often steep slopes around Jasper/ Banff (and I have monitored horse-logging operations). 

The lodgepole pine stands in these national parks are now very heavily hit by mountain pine beetle ( I viewed them this year as I drove down the icefields parkway) and they will burn eventually. This is a natural cycle and part of lodgepole pine's "strategy" to maintain itself in the ecosystem (it is a pioneer species, and wouldn't be there without fire). The stands will naturally regenerate to mainly pine.

Comment: Indeed, rent-control stiffles the development of housing,especially "affordable" housing.  New units are expensive to build and, unless you're giftedMUPTEs or other incentives, most investors are very hesitant to build.  Moreover, those rent-control measure encourage landlords to raise rents before those controls are put into place.  As a landlord, I've always tried to "hold off" on rent raises until "turnover".  We have "newer" tenants paying $100/monthk more than tenants who have been there for years.  Impose rent controls and I'm forced to raise all those rents now before it's put into place.  Creation of an "artificial market" with rent-control is a simplistic approach to the complex issues surrounding the shortage of affordable housing.  Like most simplistic solutions it creates more problems than it solves.  

Those "no-cause" terminations of rental contracts, BTW, are generally a "compromise" solution to dealing with a problem tenant.  Easier, cleaner for everyone than an FED.

Comment: The TPP was negotiated in utter secrecy by government appointees and corporate lawyers.  Interested officials outside the negotiating process were either refused access to the text, or could view only under strict supervision.  At no time was the general public invited to participate or observe. Rather than a "trade" pact, the TPP appears to be an "investors" pact which fundamentally changes the relationships between government, the people, and transnational capital - favouring the latter. Analysis conducted for the Canadian government revealed that the TPP would result in a net economic gain of 0.127% (less than 5 billion dollars), and that only over the next 22 years (see Global Affairs Canada "Economic Impact of Canada's Potential Participation in the Trans-Pacific Partnership"). 

So the idea is to fundamentally alter the structure of our country, quite possibly in very negative damaging ways, so to grow our economy barely more than one-tenth of 1% over next two decades.

Comment: People appear to be running around like headless chickens with this article.  I suggest rereading it for comprehension.  What the initial forward look stated was that, subject to several caveats, the accumulated DEBT as a percentage of GDP would go to zero by 2040.  Now it seems it may be 2050.  Where we are now is DEBT is about 31% of GDP.  Now, to reduce the DEBT to effectively zero will require DEFICITS (calculated annually) to become SURPLUSES -- something with which we are already familiar from the previous Liberal government.

Short-term I don't really have a problem with DEFICIT spending, although I will concede this year's $27-28B amount is pretty large.  And, the forward DEFICIT projections point to a DEFICIT about half this year's amount in about 3 years.  Hopefully that trend will be maintained in Trudeau's 2nd term.  But again, lots of variables in the mix.

Finally, let's not forget that Mr Harper ran up a couple of eye-watering deficits of $50B+ during his tenure.

Comment: That is completely incorrect. Obama released his birth certificate in June 2008, while still a candidate, and in fact was the first presidential candidate in US history ever to release his actual birth certificate. No sitting president ever had released their birth certificate before. Some did afterward, but never while in office. Obama set a precedent by doing so.

What he did two years later was release the long form, for which he had to receive special permission from the state of Hawaii. But he had already released his official certified birth certificate in 2008 before the election.

Comment: For once, there's some actual content in a Jenkins piece.  But, as always, party-line thinking.

Jenkins seems not to understand that voter registrations are not votes. It is illegal to provide false information when you register to vote, but it is not exactly "election fraud," which would required a fraudulently registered voted to cast a ballot.  That is the part that's missing from Jenkins' analysis.  I don't doubt that many states have deceased or now out-of-state people on their rolls.  That might create opportunities for election fraud, but unless you can show that there are people trying to exploit those opportunities, you haven't proven that any election is tainted.  According to the Brennan Center at New York University, " . . . voter fraud is very rare, voter impersonation is nearly non-existence, and much of the problems associated with alleged fraud . . .relates to unintentional mistakes by voters or election administrators. "https://www.brennancenter.org/issues/voter-fraud

Comment: "going to have to settle for less". Apartment and condo living is not settling for less if that is your choice. We started out in an apartment, bought a house, lived in it for almost 30 years and now are back in the same apartment building. Being relieved of the burdens of property ownership is bliss. We brought our son up in the house but now believe it would have been great to have brought him up in the apartment. It's downtown with kid friendly attractions all around, walk to the subway and lots of other kids around as well. We could do with some more park areas, but I think streets are safer for kids in the centre of town than in the suburbs. There are always lots of people around to help a youngster if she or he gets into trouble. Most kids around here walk to school. Most suburban kids don't or can't. In the end it's a matter of choice and affordability, but the stigma against high rise living should be removed.

Comment: Actually your statement "The trawler bycatch tonnage of halibut and chinook salmon is greater than the quota for the directed fisheries." isn't accurate. Actually it looks like the cod longline fishery in the gulf had a substantially higher halibut bycatch rate of 31%. Another example of other fleets having a higher bycatch rate would be last year about 30 rockfish species, which includes yellow eye rockfish, became prohibited from retention after too many got caught by fixed gear vessels and had to be discarded at a nearly 100% mortality rate. No one wants to see fisheries overfished, thats not a good deal. Alaska fisheries both state & federal are regarded as well managed and sustainable fisheries that have taken some lessons learned from other fisheries such as Atlantic cod. That fishery judged biomass based off of catch rates. As boats became more efficient at catching cod they calculated the biomass getting bigger n fished it down to an unsustainable rate. Kinda like how the IPHC

Comment: No, Mr. Trump is not diverse. A single individual can't be diverse. Diversity is about collections or groups of people, the more diverse when they include more genders, types, backgrounds, ages, etc., and the less diverse when they are more uniform in the same factors. 

And I'll help you out with why the "honor diversity" crowd doesn't like Trump. I honor diversity and I really object to what Mr. Trump has said in public about Mexicans, Muslims, women, blacks, handicapped, and so on. I don't hate him, but I do seriously object to his candidacy for president of this country. I can't speak for others. 

Furthermore, hating an individual can't be bigotry. Bigotry is about hating groups and collections of people for their characteristics, gender, background, color, religion, preferences, age, etc. Disliking a person, even hating that person, for what he or she says, believes, or does, rather than that person's classification, is not bigotry.

Comment: That reminds me,...

I was once travelling back to Canada from a period overseas.   This was back in the late 1980s.

I was carrying one item that was over the customs declaration amount.   At the time, it was $40 per item for periods outside of Canada of 6 months or more.  Well, the first Border Svcs Agent took a dim view of my $60 purchase (a porcelain vase -- a gift for someone) and sent me for further questioning.

Well - lo and behold -- I got stuck in a line right behind the Canadian National Rifle Squad, who were returning (on the same flight) from a competition in Germany.

Long story short, you do not ever want to get stuck in line behind this squad at Customs.   It takes a looooooong time to review everything.   It must have taken close to an hour.

And then, when I reached the agent and handed him my paper with the $60 vase infraction noted, he looked at my sad, tired face, looked back at the paper, and said "Have a nice day."  He said it twice.  I was in shock and left.

Comment: You said "However, the law states that a driver must yield right-of-way to the pedestrian any time a person is waiting to cross the street." 

This is true at a marked, or unmarked crosswalk (an intersection) but not everywhere along the road 

RCW 46.61.240 says "Every pedestrian crossing a roadway at any point other than within a marked crosswalk or within an unmarked crosswalk at an intersection shall yield the right of way to all vehicles upon the roadway." 

Pedestrians should be aware of this, and not just walk out in front of vehicles anywhere on the road, assuming they always have he right of way.

Comment: I concur, in particular, with your observation that the 'Story of Some of Us' skips over 600 years or more of vital, formative Canadian history. 

Nova Scotia and New Brunswick have understandably taken umbrage with the notion that Canada began in 1608 at Quebec. Newfoundland and Labrador has yet to express its indignation - reflecting perhaps its 68 year resignation with repeated attempts to minimize its historical relevance to the evolution of Canada. That's what happens when you're late signing up. Still, Sir Humphrey might be miffed that his 1583 expedition to the then well established fishing station at St. John's to claim the region for the English cost him not only his life but his place in history.

Comment: I grew up in Lincoln County, Montana.  Lincoln County is about one and a half times the size of Delaware and has about 19,000 people, the same number it had when I was in grade school back in the 1960's.  Almost all of the land in Lincoln County is Forest Service land.  There is a small amount of farm land and three small towns.  By your concept of land ownership, the people who live in Lincoln County should have no say in what happens in Lincoln County because there are so few of them.  So the only real industry in Lincoln County was shut down in 1980 by court injunctions.  There is now no logging or lumber industry in the county.  
You say it was because the people who lived there abused the resources.  What you leave out is the fact that the resources were always controlled by the Forest Service, and that if anyone cut a tree, it was first purchased from the Forest Service, and there was a contract, which, if the purchaser deviated from, they would never get another timber sale.

Comment: Exactly. Any car manufactured in July, 2015 will have one more year of depreciation than one manufactured in July, 2016. Typical first year depreciation is about 20%. Second year is about 15%.

Dealerships intentionally introduced 'model year' to confuse the buyer. Depending on manufacturer, model year 2017 could be manufactured anytime starting from February to July 2016. This way if you happen to buy July 2015 car in July 2016, you will be purchasing a year old car that is technically 2016 model year. However, resale value is determined largely by production date that is tied to VIN.

Often times such 'lingering' cars are removed from stock. Manufacturers incentivize dealers to "buy them" and declare them sold. At upscale brands these are used as loaners. In case of KIA, they just sit on the lot or sold to rental fleets. If you are dealing with one of these, dealer received additional discount from manufacturer, anywhere from 10-25% off, and should be passing these to buyer.

Comment: I, too, have walked alone all over urban Japan late into the night (well past the time the adult-oriented vending machines are unshuttered) and armed with a trusty camera, a 66" tripod, plus about 30 lbs of related lenses and gear.  Even crossing through darkened public parks with homeless men congregated here and there, never did I feel intimidated nor was I ever hassled.

Make no mistake, it's nice - well, liberating really - to sojourn in a country like that. But there are some very cogent reasons that suggest it's unlikely we can translate what works there, over here. 

First, while it's less taken for granted than decades ago, the average Japanese still harbors a measured respect for authority figures, be they police, teachers, or the elderly.  Not obsequious, but it's there. 

Second, ideas such as privacy and community policing are expressed differently, to the point that some married police couples are assigned to live in and socially interact with the communities they patrol.

Comment: Margaret,

As any economist will be pleased to explain to you, increasing the price of goods that cause harm (whether they are cigarettes, alcohol or gasoline) will tend to reduce consumption, and in the case of fossil fuels, GHG emissions. This is a fundamental and unassailable economic fact of life. The program will therefore result in reduced GHG emissions (which is its purpose).

While you may or may not agree with any particular program to which the funds applied, the government has committed to spend the cap and trade proceeds on projects and programs which further reduce GHG emissions. Most of which would appear to have substantial merit.  Eg, a program to facilitate bicycling to Go Transit stations, would provide health benefits to the participants, while reducing air pollution and easing traffic congestion.

Comment: There are traffic simulation programs that can model anything. What happens if the yellow light is 2 seconds longer?  What if there is a delay between red & green so for an instance all ways see red?  The lack of use of these tools drives me crazy (I worked in simulation for years).

This article uses the term 'bottleneck'.  A bottleneck is the slowest part of a system.  To get the most of any system you 'elevate the bottleneck', you make sure there is never a gap feeding it and it is never blocked on the far side.  In their model the bottleneck never sees any gap in cars.

Their analysis holds true IF the rate of movement through a bottleneck is fixed.  However, traffic doesn't work like that.  A cross section of road can handle the same volume of cars moving at different rates IF the space between the cars is also different.  i.e. bigger gap & faster cars or smaller gap and slower cars...  I expect people will both slow down and leave space in a zipper method - which will be slower.

"Unemployment rate" means the rate of people actively looking for jobs.

Comment: You'd agree Jim, I think, that we  Americans have an awkward time talking about issues of race, religion, etc., and part of it is the terminology-- like calling someone who hates Muslims "racists."  While it's easy to joke about our current gaffes and to ridicule attempts at new terms, it's a lot harder to actually find a better solution.  "Ethnic", which includes racial, national, and religious groups, would often be a more accurate term than "race."  These are all just social definitions, after all.

It's unfortunate "ethnocentrism" (meaning "my ethnic group is the center  of the world") is such an unwieldy  term or it might be more widely used.   And who would want to be accused of being "ethnocentric?"

BTW, I've coined a new term,  the opposite of ethnocentrism:  "Ethnoguiltism", for those who are obsessed with the idea that their own ethnic group is the cause of all the world's problems.  A balance is needed.

Comment: Appendix ?  Reminds me of a story-

A newly ordained rabbi was so filled with the sacredness of the act when he performed his first bris that he saved the foreskin. As time went by, he saved each foreskin and had them in a mason-jar on his mantle. One day a friend who made leather-goods came to visit. He asked about the foreskins and the rabbi explained how he happened to have them. The leather guy persuaded the rabbi to let him have the foreskins, promising he would make something out-of-them. A week later, he returns and presents the rabbi with a beautiful hand-tooled/stitched/ engraved/dyed wallet of the highest quality. The rabbi had never seen anything so beautiful and said to his friend " How much do I owe you ? " (hoping to get a freebee) The leather guy without batting an eye replied - " $350 bucks. " 
The rabbi said " Too much for just a wallet " 
The leather guy said - " But this is no ordinary wallet - If you stroke it - it becomes a suitcase ! "
" Sold " the rabbi said....

Comment: Unemployment including for youth are at record low levels in both Canada and the US right now - yes there is an increase in part-time and precarious work but many people in this day and age hold more than one job or do a side gig like uber or pizza delivery which combined works out to full time hours. The provinces have already and in particular a select few have pledged to hike minimum wages to catch up with inflation. The feds are increasing child benefits for families in the middle class and below to act as a basic income. Low income seniors and working individuals also are receiving higher tax benefits.
